articles.headline: Palins Repeatedly Pressed Case Against Trooper
articles.snippet: Gov. Sarah Palin, her husband and seven administration officials made three dozen contacts to a commissioner about the status of a trooper.
articles.abstract: Gov. Sarah Palin, her husband and seven administration officials made three dozen contacts to a commissioner about the status of a trooper.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — The 2007 state fair was days away when Alaska’s public safety commissioner, Walt Monegan, took another call about one of his troopers, Michael Wooten. This time, the director of Gov. Sarah Palin’s Anchorage office was on the line.

articles.headline: Plan B: Flood Banks With Cash
articles.snippet: The government needs to decide which banks it is sure are worth saving, and pump capital into them directly.
articles.abstract: The government needs to decide which banks it is sure are worth saving, and pump capital into them directly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banks are supposed to lend money, but they aren’t doing very much of it these days. That is not the only cause of the global recession that is unfolding, but it is hard to see how economies can begin to recover without functioning financial systems.

articles.headline: Lawmakers Weigh Plan for Stimulus
articles.snippet: The Democratic leadership in Congress is considering another fiscal stimulus proposal to spark spending by consumers and city and state governments.
articles.abstract: The Democratic leadership in Congress is considering another fiscal stimulus proposal to spark spending by consumers and city and state governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve and Congress are pushing out close to $1 trillion to repair the nation’s financial system and to encourage lending. But that is not enough to revive the economy. Spending has to resume.

articles.headline: Morgan Under Assault
articles.snippet: After another rough day for Morgan Stanley — its stock fell 26 percent, and new doubts arose about a $9 billion infusion from Japan — it seemed Morgan’s chief, John Mack, can’t catch a break.
articles.abstract: After another rough day for Morgan Stanley — its stock fell 26 percent, and new doubts arose about a $9 billion infusion from Japan — it seemed Morgan’s chief, John Mack, can’t catch a break.
articles.lead_paragraph: John J. Mack just cannot catch a break.

articles.headline: Insurance Industry Joins Banking Giants on the Hot Seat
articles.snippet: Insurance companies are now being battered like Wall Street banks were last month, suggesting a similar round of consolidation and recapitalization.
articles.abstract: Insurance companies are now being battered like Wall Street banks were last month, suggesting a similar round of consolidation and recapitalization.
articles.lead_paragraph: Months after the stocks of big Wall Street financial firms first came under attack, insurance companies are now being battered, suggesting that a similar round of consolidation and recapitalization may be in store for that industry.

articles.headline: U.S. Auto Shares Plunge on a Grim Sales Forecast
articles.snippet: A dire new forecast for global vehicle sales battered the shares of auto companies on Thursday, particularly General Motors, whose stock plunged more than 31 percent.
articles.abstract: A dire new forecast for global vehicle sales battered the shares of auto companies on Thursday, particularly General Motors, whose stock plunged more than 31 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  A dire new forecast for global vehicle sales battered the shares of auto companies on Thursday, particularly General Motors, whose stock plunged more than 31 percent and was the hardest hit of the 30 companies in the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

articles.headline: Regulators Approve Wells Fargo Takeover of Wachovia
articles.snippet: Federal antitrust regulators approved the acquisition of Wachovia by Wells Fargo, bringing the battle for the troubled bank to an end.
articles.abstract: Federal antitrust regulators approved the acquisition of Wachovia by Wells Fargo, bringing the battle for the troubled bank to an end.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal antitrust regulators on Friday approved the acquisition of the troubled bank, the Wachovia Corporation, by Wells Fargo, the West Coast bank, bringing the battle for the bank to an end.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: As Crisis Spreads, Global Approach Weighed
articles.snippet: The U.S. and Britain appear to be coming to a common solution a day before a meeting of financial leaders.
articles.abstract: The U.S. and Britain appear to be coming to a common solution a day before a meeting of financial leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United States and Britain appear to be converging on a similar blueprint for stemming the financial chaos sweeping the world, one day before a crucial meeting of leaders begins in Washington that the White House hopes will result in a more coordinated response.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Edmund L. Andrews

articles.headline: As Fears Ease, Baghdad Sees Walls Tumble
articles.snippet: The dismantling of blast walls is the most visible sign of change in Baghdad as the surge strategy draws to a close.
articles.abstract: The dismantling of blast walls is the most visible sign of change in Baghdad as the surge strategy draws to a close.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Alissa J. Rubin, Stephen Farrell and Erica Goode, and written by Ms. Rubin and Mr. Farrell.
articles.byline: By Stephen Farrell, Alissa J. Rubin, Sam Dagher and Erica Goode

articles.headline: Whiplash Ends a Roller Coaster Week
articles.snippet: For three straight days, the stock market collapsed in the last hour of trading. On Friday, it merely swooned.
articles.abstract: For three straight days, the stock market collapsed in the last hour of trading. On Friday, it merely swooned.
articles.lead_paragraph: For three straight days, the stock market collapsed in the last hour of trading. On Friday, it merely swooned.
